1:
Ballerina Barbie is the oldest doll in my collection, and the only Barbie that precedes the Superstar mold. She has the TNT (Twist N Turn) face mold that I was scared of as a child. Uniquely, the crown is stuck in her hair, in not sure what with but it’s very secure. I marked her hair as saran, but I am honestly not entirely sure if that is the correct fiber. It is absolutely not kanekalon or any type of modern nylon, but it could possibly be saran. There is also a mechanism inside of this line of dolls that made Barbie’s arms and legs move when she bent forward, but it is notoriously fragile. My doll is miraculously still in one piece despite my reputation for breaking things but part of the soft plastic of one of her bend-n-snap legs has ripped. This happened before I bought her, so it was not my fault. Additionally, my doll does not have her original outfit (minus one shoe). Instead, she is wearing a period accurate fashion pack, Best Buy Fashions 7814, but it is missing the belt.

- Daniel
171:
Capitalizing off of the success of Superstar Barbie, Mattel released a 17 inch version of my favorite fashion doll. Rather than the iconic pink gown, this doll came in a silver ensemble. The doll came with a leotard, a skirt, and a pair of pants so consumers could mix and match. The doll also came with a stand, shoes, and some jewelry. Of course, I bought this doll 45 years after she left stores, so my doll came with none of these pieces. I probably shouldn’t have bought this doll without her original outfit but she’s a Superstar Barbie and I couldn’t pass her up. There are also many fashion packs released in the late 70s just like the Superstar fashions in the standard scale but they are also very expensive. Oops.

2:
In 1976, Mattel changed the world with the launch of Superstar Barbie. Shifting from the peasant dresses and the Malibu bathing suits to the gorgina disco gowns and feather boas, Superstar Barbie shifted the brand into the Barbie pink glamour we know and love today. She was the first doll to use the Superstar mold, which is also the mold that didn’t terrify me as a child. Identifying this doll was a journey. I originally assumed that miss Barbie was on the right body, and the closest facial screening with that body type was 1983 Great Shape Barbie (a.k.a. "Toy Story" Barbie). However, the eyebrows were too different. So, I got curious and took her head off, as you do. I checked the stamp on the inner rim, and the country make did not match the body, which confirmed that this poor doll was on the wrong body. Next, I threw the body away because most of the fingers were broken off and the feet were all chewed. I had already washed it but it was just gross, so it had to go. I decided to give the remaining head another spa treatment, which was when I noticed that there was some short white thread rooted on each side of Barbie’s head. I was very confused, but I quickly figured out that this was the remains of a wedding veil. I also noticed that my doll has a slight haircut but it’s entirely possible that this was done in the factory during the repackaging process. Flash forward several months, I was looking at a 70s Barbie Instagram account that showed how someone restored Superstar Barbie’s original hairstyle. They redid the white string which I initially thought was just them being quirky and different until I looked through the comments and they said that the holes were from the factory. After checking the factory hairstyles of 1978 Beautiful Bride and 1980 Roller Skating, and then apologizing to Jonah via a 4,000-word essay about the importance of not wasting his time (just kidding I drew him a picture of the edit content button covered in glitter), I updated the spreadsheet with the correct information. For my picture, I borrowed someone else’s body and I dressed her in my reproduction Superstar’s outfit. This is my favorite fashion doll of all time and even though she’s currently just a head and one of the most common Barbies, she is one of my most prized pieces in my collection.

- Daniel
3:
This is the first "My First" Barbie released, and she has a simplified version of the standard Twist N Turn body. Instead of bend n snap legs, My First Barbie has solid legs, one bent and one straight. Her head is also limited in movement, it can only move left and right. The clothes were supposed to be easier to put on and take off. The box contained extra outfit pieces so the child could mix and match fashions. I got this doll used so I only have some of the clothes, but I personally think that tying laces isn’t the easiest mechanism for young children to use. Velcro wasn’t widely used on Barbie clothes at the time, so I guess laces were the next best option. Also important about this doll is that her exact facial screening was reused for other My First Barbies and other dolls at the time. I was lucky that I found my doll in her original outfit. She had never been taken out of her original hairstyle which was very helpful for identification but not very fun to clean up. This doll is very unique in my collection as I don’t have many dolls from this time period.

- Daniel
397:
Oh dear. This doll did not age well. This is one of the most iconic western themed Barbie dolls, but she has a winking mechanism that does not work well. Since this doll is over 40 years old, the winking mechanism has drooped over time and so Barbie’s eyes never look right. Similar to Kissing Barbie from 1978, this doll has a modified body with a button on her back that pushes gears in her head to make her wink. Also, rather than having a standard vinyl head, Barbie’s face wraps around the gears with a staple in the back. This looks rather terrifying to the unsuspecting viewer. I got this doll used, so I am missing everything except her jumpsuit. The doll originally came with a cowboy hat, boots, a hairbrush, comb, mirror, six headshots, and stamping tools so she could give her autograph to the other dolls. I’m sure Jonah and my other dolls are devastated that they could not get Western Barbie’s autograph. I don’t think this doll is as scary as the original Barbie face mold but she’s still pretty horrifying.

This doll included a stand, a sheet of cardboard accessories, and a pair of black standard Barbie pumps. I bought this Barbie still in the box, and 32 years in a box was not the best condition for this poor doll to stay in. Everything was fine when I took her out and cleaned her, but a week later when I looked at her on display, I noticed that her shoes had mysteriously broken into pieces. 26:
The 2002 Birthday Barbie is almost identical to the 2001 Happy Birthday Barbie. The only differences is that the 2001 dated doll has the 1991 body while my doll has the 1999 body. Additionally, the child sized crown in the 2001 release is silver while the 2002 one is hot pink. The 2001 doll has a more simplified skirt with no printed pattern and purple mesh while the 2002 doll has a printed ribbon patterned skirt and pink mesh. The bows on the waists are also very different. The 2001 bow is smaller, a darker pink, and off-center compared to the 2002 doll. The cardboard presents that both dolls came with have different patterns but are otherwise the same. Unfortunately, my doll’s cardboard present did not survive 21 years of living in a box. The elastic holding it in place dry rotted and stained the cardboard, so I did not keep it. The ribbon in this doll’s hair also did not survive because it was originally attached to her hair entirely with an elastic that has dry rotted. Most unfortunate of all is that when I was cleaning this doll, her arm snapped off. I am able to get it to rest in place for display and it was previously glued back into place but when I took the picture of this doll her arm broke off again. That’s very unfortunate.

172:
2003 Ballet Star Barbie was one of many budget slim boxed ballerina Barbies sold in the early 2000s. This one is very interesting to me. First of all, this line reuses the name of a standard released Barbie released in 2000, and then again in 2001. Barbie reuses names all the time but I was surprised it was done so soon without any connection between the lines lore-wise. What I find most interesting about this doll is the body that she has. She has the 1966 Twist N Turn body which was in the process of being phased out in this era. Additionally, she has stiff, non-bending legs which is uncommon for the early 2000s. Her legs are painted to give the illusion of colored tights that match her leotard. Another interesting part of this doll is her arms. They are the pre-Superstar straight arms that were the standard for Barbie in the 1960s and 70s. She reminds me a lot of the My First Barbies from the 1980s (I only have the 1980 one). Other than the Generation Girl mold and the ballet theme (although some My First Barbies were partially ballet themed), the biggest difference is that this doll has full neck articulation which really surprised me. I wonder at what point the stiff neck was considered a worthwhile cost-cutting measure. Interestingly, Barbie is the purple themed doll in this line while Teresa is the pink doll. This is just a lot of weird decisions only I would find interesting. I think this doll has such a beautiful face but I don’t think her makeup matches her outfit well.

27:
Jamin’ in Jamacia was the first My Scene movie. My Scene was a Barbie adjacent line that was released as a response to Bratz in 2002. Until the 2009 legal ruling that Bratz was property of Mattel, My Scene existed as a Barbie version, where the dolls had Barbie bodies but larger, much more Bratz-like heads. The shoes were sized so they fit on standard Barbies feet but appeared oversized similar to Bratz dolls. As a result, My Scene dolls end up being very tall while fully dressed. In the My Scene universe, Barbie is the main character, and the other dolls are her friends as they live in New York city. My Scene also carried over elements from the Generation Girls line that was canceled because of 9/11. In this movie, the My Scene characters take a trip to Jamacia to participate in a music contest. Madison, this doll, is the manager of the band. I got my doll used and unfortunately, I do not have a single piece to this doll other than the doll herself. Madison originally came with a DVD of the movie, a doll beach chair, two outfits and various little accessories. I wish I at least had one of her outfits, but she has really gorgeous distinct makeup so it’s ok. My doll is wearing the dress of my childhood Sporty Style Madison doll that is unfortunately no longer with me. I don’t know what happened to her but I’m very glad her outfit gets to stay with the character.

This doll was released in 2003 as part of the first wave of the DC Comics collection. The second wave also included this doll, but the release was exactly the same and I do not still have the box so I cannot check the box dates, so I went with the older release. She was also released with a motorcycle playset, but the doll had a standard Barbie body. The single doll release, which I have has the Ever Flex body. The Ever Flex body was a short lived sculpt from the 2000s that put wires in the doll’s arms and legs for additional flexibility. In the 1960s and 70s, Barbie’s younger siblings Tutti and Todd (rest in peace) had similar leg mechanisms. Many of the pieces to this doll disappeared, but I still have one of the boots. I know nothing about superheroes or comic books. I am not interested in learning about superheroes or comic books. 62:
The Big City Big Dreams movie was the first time white, blonde Barbie ("Malibu") met Black Barbie ("Brooklyn"). This doll is a budget release because she has simplified clothes and accessories. She also has flat feet, but they aren’t as huge and scary as the 2000s flat feet. She is undoubtedly a budgeted release of the Malibu Singing doll. She also lacks the singing mechanism of the main doll. This doll is honestly very mid and I really wish that Mattel put more effort into her. The print of her dress only goes on one side which is very lazy. At least this doll has saran hair.

- Daniel
390:
This doll features the signature look Margot Robbie wears in the Barbie movie. The dress is extremely high quality and I was very impressed. Unfortunately, the shoes keep falling off so I have to be careful with her. Additionally, her hair bow is held in by those evil plastic T tabs that I despise but for my own sanity I pretend I do not see it. I feel like the bangs absolutely ruin the face of this doll. She gave the world the first look of the new Margot Robbie face mold and the bangs (which aren’t even accurate to the movie; she should have curtain bangs), and it looks absolutely awful. It looks nothing like the actress. The other dolls, who do not have bangs look a million times better. I feel bad because she’s otherwise amazing but those horrible bangs completely take away from the face.

- Daniel
63:
I fell in love with the 2022 Birthday Barbie the moment I saw her. I love how unique her silhouette is, and every detail is perfect. I do think this doll was a bit overpriced, so I’m glad I bought her on sale. Her ponytail reminds me of Barbie #1 without the hideous bangs and the massive bow on her waist is so campy. I love the tiny splashes of color on this doll’s dress but it is still mainly baby pink (my favorite shade of pink). I do wish this doll wore a necklace but I guess necklaces weren’t really in style. I honestly can’t tell if this doll has the Millie face mold but she looks very pretty regardless.

- Daniel
389:
For some cursed reason, Chelsea joined Barbie in the Jungle Series of Cutie Reveal dolls. She essentially wears miniature versions of the four different animals Barbie dresses up as in this series. See the Barbie Elephant doll for a more detailed description of this line of dolls because I don’t want to talk about it again. This doll is pink monkey themed but unlike her sister, Chelsea does not have any fluffy sweatpants. To be honest, these dolls were pretty lazy compared to Barbie. The "revealed" outfit is also very ugly. I genuinely do not understand why anyone would seriously purchase this doll unless they are a small child or enjoy tormenting their friends who have to upload them to websites.

- Daniel
324:
The Jungle series is the fourth series of Cutie Reveal dolls. Honestly, this is one of the most ridiculous dolls I own. This is an unboxing (I do not like that word; just say open L) gimmick doll where you remove Barbie’s animal costume and change her outfit into a tracksuit. I don’t really understand the vision because the dolls aren’t blind packaged, but apparently this line has been very successful with children. I bought this doll entirely because I thought it was funny. Jonah specifically told me that he would not put any of these dolls on the website, but I chose not to listen. Apart from the cursed concept of these dolls, the Elephant doll is honestly gorgeous and I’m so glad I impulsively bought her.

- Daniel
64:
Barbie Extra #14 is very obsessed with 1980s Barbie. Almost every piece of this doll’s outfit is branded with the 80s Barbie logo. Apart from the jewelry and shoes everything is also Barbie pink. Her pet also has their own car that’s Barbie pink. My absolute favorite detail about this doll is her purse. It is a clutch bag that is stylized to be an 80s slim boxed Barbie package. That’s such a cute detail that put effort into the nostalgia bait. I honestly can’t say I like this doll more than my other full-sized Barbie Extra but I still really love her.

- Daniel
65:
The first thing I notice when I look at Barbie Extra #20 is her face. It’s an older mold that I haven’t seen on a Barbie since the 2000s. The second thing I notice is her sweater, with the plastic butterfly charms textured as if they were also made of wool. Because this is a Barbie Extra doll, she comes with an unnecessary number of accessories that honestly do not match her outfit well, so I did not include her purse, sunglasses, pet, or her pet’s sunglasses. My biggest complaint with this doll is her shorts. I would have much preferred if she had some cute bell bottom jeans with this outfit, especially with those cowboy boots. I might be completely delusional though because I think that bell bottom jeans make every outfit better. I also really love this doll’s hair. Obviously, I appreciate that it’s purple but I’m also very glad that it’s saran because this is a modern Mattel doll, and I don’t trust them to not use polypropylene on their main playline releases. All my complaining aside, I really really love this doll. I think her jewelry is absolutely adorable and she’s one of the best Barbie Extra dolls released at the time I’m writing this.

- Daniel
66:
Extra Mini is a spin off to Barbie Extra and speculated to be a response to MGA’s LOL Surprise tots. However, the Extra Mini dolls are closer in scale to the LOL Surprise Tweens. Their release dates are pretty close together, so I think it’s more likely Mattel’s response to the tots. Despite this, the Extra Minis have fabric clothes and rooted hair. They have cartoonishly large heads in contrast to the regular Barbie Extra dolls, who have regular Barbie heads and bodies. Also, unlike the full-sized dolls, the Extra Mini dolls come with stands. I don’t know the reason for this inconsistency, but I assume that Mattel is aware of the fact that it is much harder to find 3rd party stands for mini dolls. Anyway, I go back and forth with my opinion of this doll. I think she’s very cute, but her face is a bit jarring. She is way simpler than the LOL Surprise Tweens so I honestly can’t say that she’s very impressive.

- Daniel
325:
Barbie Looks #10 is part of the Barbie Signature umbrella of "playline collector" dolls, as in they are packaged as collector dolls and are more expensive than playline dolls, but they are widely available and far from the price range of Silkstone "adult collector" type dolls. The name Barbie Signature seems to be an evolution of the Barbie Collector dolls from my childhood, which were the same idea of "playline collector". The Looks line was first released in 2022, and the first series (which this doll was part of) featured neutral colors and silver chrome. They also all had the Made To Move body, which gave the dolls the highest amount of articulation on a Barbie. A restyled picture of this doll went viral within the doll community on Twitter, which is why I decided to buy her (I usually don’t pay much attention to modern Barbie because she is currently in her flop era). I think this doll is one of the most beautiful Barbies in my collection and personally I think this is one of the best dolls Mattel has made in many years.

- Daniel
67: This is a reproduction of (box dated) 1976 Superstar Barbie, which was the first doll to use the "Superstar" face mold that became Barbie’s signature face for the next twenty years. This doll also signified a harsh shift in Barbie’s aesthetic from the peasant-style fashions of the early 70s and the Malibu era to the disco style of the late 70s. Superstar Barbie is also the first doll to feature the 90-degree bent "Barbie" arms that became part of her pop culture image. The original Superstar doll was frequently repackaged, both as "Superstar Barbie" (with additional fashions, child-sized jewelry, and as a 2-pack with 1977 Superstar Ken) and as two other dolls: 1978 Beautiful Bride (I own that one :) Update: no I don’t :( ) and 1980 Roller Skating Barbie. Superstar Barbie is the earliest Barbie that didn’t scare me as a child, and I see her as the turning point from Barbie’s early years into the absolute icon she became by the end of the 20th century. There are some slight differences between this reproduction and the original doll. The original Superstar is much more orange in skin tone and her makeup is thicker (but there was frequent facial variations at the time). My doll also has a bit of a misprint, she is missing some of the eye shadow on one of her eyelids. Superstar Barbie is my favorite fashion doll of all time and I love her very much.
436:
This doll was the first leak for the Barbie Movie dolls. I remember being so excited because I thought this doll looked really good while still looking like Ryan Gosling. Looking back, I think this doll looks a lot more like Life in the Dreamhouse Ken, but I still really like him. I don’t buy a lot of male dolls because the female dolls are usually more interesting and detailed, but I am so glad I brought this Ken. He has rooted hair, which has been absent from flop-era Kens, for a start. His clothes are also a really nice quality material and I really appreciate that the faux buttons are added on and not printed. The shorts also have working pockets which is so rare with modern Barbie dolls. Ken also came with a surfboard which I appreciate but I wish it had some printed details. I really like this doll’s outfit because it reminds me of something my friends would wear. I could give you a detailed description of how Gideon and Jonah would style this Ken’s shirt right now but I’m not sure if they want me exposing their fashion choices. I would never dress like that personally, but people I love do, so I love this doll very much. Of course, Barbie is better, but Barbie is always better. 

Quick note, I wrote this and my description for the corresponding Barbie before I saw the movie so the only context I had was the marketing.
409: Kelly was Barbie’s toddler-to-preschool-aged sister who debuted in 1995. In 2010, she was discontinued and the character was renamed Chelsea. She was also aged-up to be in elementary school. Interestingly, Kelly was named Shelly in Europe and is the only Roberts sister (for those who don’t know, Barbie’s last name is Roberts). Kelly also had a friend named Chelsie, but she was gone by the time the Chelsea era began. Now we’ve gone through the Kelly introduction, I’ll go into more detail about this doll. Eatin’ Fun Kelly came with a highchair and various little foods. The gimmick was that you (Barbie) were teaching her how to behave and feeding her (I’m sorry I don’t know how to take care of children). The doll had a special mechanism where if you pushed a lever on her back her arm raised, mimicking an uncooperative child. I got this doll used from my friend Gideon, who probably also got her secondhand as a child. I don’t believe I have any this doll’s pieces but that’s ok. Her original outfit is very ugly anyway so I’m not that upset.
412: Tommy is Ken’s little brother who is the same age as Kelly. They appear to be friends. In this set, Tommy and Kelly are playing with a child-sized truck. This Tommy is near identical, including his outfit, to the Tommy from Big Brother Ken & Baby Brother Tommy but without the mouth hole (so Ken could feed him) and arm-moving mechanism (so he could wave). This playset featured a tiny pink truck and connector thing (sorry I don’t know what it’s called). There’s also a battery-operated feature but I got it secondhand from Gideon who also got it secondhand, so it no longer works and I am too lazy to look it up. This doll has cut hair so what once was a bowl cut now sticks up all over the place. I did my best but it still doesn’t look very good. See Kelly Club Lots of Secrets Clubhouse Detective Tommy for how this doll’s hair is supposed to look.
427: This Kelly has a unique body. Her legs have pointed ballerina feet and her arms are articulated for additional movement. She also has painted on tights and ballet shoes but unlike the Barbie she was sold with, her ankles do not articulate. Also like her Barbie, I got this doll from Gideon, but I’m pretty sure I do not have her outfit. In the playset that came with the doll, Kelly was able to "really dance" by being attached to a mechanism that made her spin. She could be posed so she looked like she was dancing. This Kelly is newer than most of the others Gideon gave me, but I prefer her facial screening to the 90s dolls.
429: Cut & Style was a reoccurring gimmick with Barbie. See my Cut & Style Rapunzel doll for a more detailed description of this hair gimmick. The original Cut & Style dolls had refillable hair cartages for their undercuts but that was a lot messier. This doll was given to me by Gideon, but the connectors for the hair extensions were already removed. The extensions and accessories were also lost but I’m not bothered because that’s kinda gross. This doll’s dress reminds me so much of the dolls from my childhood, which were very much from 2010 so that makes sense. Honestly, I’m not a big fan of the green, sorry Gid. The dress is very ugly but it’s very much giving Candy Land so it’s kinda camp. I’m not the biggest fan of hair gimmick dolls but this Teresa has lovely kanekalon hair so she gets bonus points from me. The best part though is definitely her dark purple makeup, but purple makeup is my favorite so I might be a little delusional.
406: This doll was released under the first line (obviously) of Li’l Friends of Kelly. Because this was Gideon’s doll, she was actually a Li’l Friend of Shelly because that was Kelly’s name in the UK. Marissa is the first Latina friend of Kelly and she is very cute. She has kanekalon hair which is very much appreciated on this website. Once again, she is missing her outfit and loaning the romper from Power Wheels Kelly (who I do not have at this time). I hope she can one day be reunited with her own outfit.
420: The Adventures of the Li’l Friends came in the most darling little costumes. In this wave, Chelsie made two appearances, but this doll is the Cowgirl one. There was a variation where she came with a little toy rocking horse. I have no evidence of this rocking horse so I don’t know which she was. The only thing she’s missing is a cute little cowgirl hat. Of course I don’t have any of her little pieces because this was another gift from Gideon but that’s absolutely ok. I’m sure she doesn’t mind borrowing from the Kelly fashions I have. This doll is one of the very few of Gideon’s that did not get a haircut, and I can’t complain about this at all because I also cut a lot of my dolls’ hair when I was a child (they are no longer with me so unfortunately will not make an appearance on this website). Chelsie is interesting to me because Kelly herself was renamed Chelsea in 2010, so I can’t help but wonder if that strained their relationship. I don’t have the answers but I personally think Jonah is to blame, and I really do believe that based on nothing (that’s an Ethan Klein quote). Here’s what Gideon thinks about this doll. I thought Cowgirl Chelsea was SO PRETTY when I was a kid. I loved her dark red hair and red lipstick and green eyes and freckles. Looking back, that was probably just my ego talking because I had most of those traits, but who would Gideon be without being full of himself? She also reminded me of my uncle’s girlfriend Kelly who was American and crocheted me a hat that I loved for so long. It was dark turquoise and really soft and also I could hide all my hair in it. She was often the main character when I played with my dolls, leading treks through snail-covered fennel plants and answering all the questions in Barbie school. She also wore my favourite outfit a lot of the time which was a denim and red plaid dress. She always wore shoes for some reason even though I usually didn’t.
421: Kayla honestly seems like a pointless character in the Kelly-verse because she looks exactly the same as Kelly but with green eyes. Kelly has green eyes sometimes so it still doesn’t mean much. Also Barbie has had at least five different friends named Kayla so like pick a new name girlypop (for once Gideon has gotten me to start saying a new buzzword instead of the other way around). In this release, Kayla is apparently playing dress-up but she is doing a boring job. She can’t even commit to a monochromatic fit because her shoes are the wrong color. Also toddlers should not be wearing high heels that’s got to be awful for their development. Apparently Gideon and his siblings hated this doll too because he had a lot of negative things to say about her when I asked for identification help. I just enjoy clowning on my dolls. Also this doll has a slight haircut so I put it into a ponytail.
422: This doll was a special Easter release that featured Kelly in various easter costumes. 3 of the 4 dolls were blonde, white Kelly, but the second Kelly as a "Funny Bunny" was Black. These dolls were released in 2001. This doll was another gift from Gideon, and to be honest I wasn’t sure if this Kelly was salvageable because most of her hair was cut off. However, I knew the chick costume was authentic Barbie the moment I saw it, so I used that as a lead when I was identifying the dolls. Luckily, the hood of the costume hides the haircut which saves me a reroot. This doll is absolutely adorable in her little costume and I’m very thankful my friend was generous enough to give her to me.
425: Here’s the boy again with his stupid bowl cut. Tommy is Ken’s little brother who was essentially the token boy in Kelly’s friend group. In this series, he is a detective for some reason. The other dolls in the line are not in similar costumes, they are going on picnics and stargazing. There were two versions of this doll released, with the same stock number. The only difference was the color of the magnifying glass they came with. I don’t know which one came with my doll because he was from Gideon’s childhood and missing all his pieces. He’s ok I guess.
432: Of Barbie’s many many careers, Beekeeper is probably one of the least appealing to me personally. I’m not afraid of bees at all, but I am impatient and bee keeping appears to be a very slow and tedious occupation. Additionally, the outfits do not slay. This doll is from Barbie’s flop era so she features some of the many sins of modern Barbara. First of all, each detail of her clothes are printed on, including the denim of her jeans. Additionally, she has the Millie face mold which is so bland. My doll also has faded face paint- well it’s not really paint because it’s the lazy pixelated printing where you can see all the tiny dots that make up her features. This Barbara is also very limited in her movement because she only has 5 points of articulation. The saving grace for this doll is that she has saran hair. I am certainly thankful for that. This doll originally came with a playset that was essentially a curated bee colony that has just been saved by Barbie. Unfortunately for those bees, I do not have the playset pieces because I got this doll second hand. I found her at a thrift store with the 2019 Gymnast Barbie and a Chelsea camper that was unfortunately missing all its pieces. I’m also missing one of this doll’s gloves so I pictured her without them. It was clear to me that this doll was never taken out of her original outfit which makes me kind of sad for Barbie because her previous owner probably didn’t give her much love and attention. I may be a judgmental father that plays blatant favorites but I’m still going to give this doll the love she deserves.
433: Barbie has been a gymnast countless times. I tried gymnastics when I was in first grade but my balance is abysmal even after 11 years of taekwondo so it was never meant to be. This doll came in a playset with various gymnastics accessories and pieces including a balance beam and an extra outfit. I got this doll secondhand wearing her spare leotard and her medal. This doll has articulated elbows and wrists which is very much appreciated for modern Barbie. She also has very short hair that is supposed to look like it’s in a top bun which I appreciate. I love dolls with short hair because they are so much rarer than dolls with long hair. Unfortunately, this doll has the Millie face and a boring screening so she does lose quite a few points but she’s still cute. I just wish she had some glitter or something, but I know nothing about gymnastics or their kind of makeup etiquette.
434: Alongside Superstar Barbie, Superstar Christie also changed the world in 1977. Christie was Barbie’s first Black friend (and friend of color), introduced in 1968. Mattel didn’t want Barbie herself to be Black until the early 1980s, but in the 70s, Christie (alternatively sometimes it was Cara) was packaged as the Black version of Barbie’s releases, but she was still seen as "Barbie’s friend". Usually, Christie dolls would feature a different face mold than their corresponding Barbie, but the Superstar dolls introduced the world to Barbie’s most iconic face, so (I’m entirely guessing here, I don’t have any evidence for this.) Superstar Christie also used the Superstar face. Christie wears a yellow version of Barbie’s iconic pink disco gown and feather boa, and she looks absolutely stunning. This doll was reproduced as a collector doll in 2021, a year before Barbie (although Superstar Barbie was reproduced in 2009 for Barbie’s 50th anniversary). Interestingly, the material of the feather boas is very different, I don’t have an original boa but from the pictures I’ve seen, Christie’s seems more accurate. If it wasn’t obvious enough, the original Superstar Barbie is my favorite fashion doll of all time so this Christie means the absolute world to me and I love her very much.
361: This is one of the most iconic Barbie of the 80s. She came in an elaborate peachy gown that I unfortunately do not have. Jonah is probably thrilled that I don’t have the outfit because he’s a hater that doesn’t like fabulous ball gowns. I would put 20 tomato emojis here but I don’t think I’m allowed. I found this doll at a thrift store with a fat head (when the neck breaks so the child shoves the head down to try and keep it on and it makes the doll’s head look wide and oddly distorted. It’s entirely fixable) and wearing 1980 Western Barbie’s jumpsuit. As soon as I saw this doll’s face I knew 2 things: 1. She was from the 80s which is a rare occurrence for me to find, and 2. This Barbie needs me to be her father and fix her neck. After the release of the Barbie movie I’ve been more gatekeep-y with Barbie because I don’t want to share but also I don’t want my favorite thing in the world to become a discarded trend. In my delusional thinking, I worried that someone else would buy this doll, realize she was broken, and throw her away. Barbie deserves better than that. Also, this doll has the added sentiment because two of my aunts had her as kinds. My mom didn’t have any Barbies, she had Sindy (see Music Star Sindy for more information), so having a Barbie my mother remembers from her own childhood is extra special. I used to have my aunts’ hand-me-down Barbies when I was very young but unfortunately they are no longer with me. Often, Peaches ‘N Cream Barbies are ugly but I think mine is stunning. I love her purple eyeshadow and coral lipstick. She is so beautiful.
362: Mattel has always been obsessed with gimmick dolls. Barbie gives a unique retrospective of how technology has evolved. The late 70s and early 80s were a particularly cursed time for gimmick Barbies. See 1980 Western Barbie for what I mean. Magic Moves Barbie isn’t as scary, but her mechanics are also dated. When you push a lever on her back, her arms move up and then her head tips back. It makes it look like she’s flipping her hair back. The mechanism is very loud, and you have to push the arms down with a little force to get them back to normal. Because this doll is almost 40 years old that stresses me out. I got this doll second-hand, so I don’t have any of her pieces and she has a haircut but that’s ok. I think she’s still very pretty and I was very happy to adopt her. This poor thing was the filthiest doll I’ve ever rescued. She was covered in what I hope was just dirt. I promised her that I would give her a nice home and never let her get to that point of filth again.
363: Barbie has been a mermaid a million times. In 1991 she was really into being blue this time. This mermaid doll is the most common one I’ve found, where they have a standard doll body and a cloth tail that slips on. Unfortunately, I got this doll used so I don’t have her tail or her bikini top. This doll has tinsel in her hair which stresses me out because it gets snagged so easily and often ends up looking awful. The tinsel has a turquoise tint to it that reminds me of the hand-me-down Barbies I had as a kid. This doll also smelled exactly like those childhood dolls that are no longer mine which was a very weird nostalgic moment. I thought this doll was from the late 80s judging by her facial screening and I’m not going to lie I was slightly disappointed she was from the 90s because 90s Barbies are so much more common, but I don’t mind now. Personally, I think Barbie should’ve gone with a purple theme instead of the blue but I forgive her.
364: As Barbie’s longest-lasting sister, Skipper has gone through a variety of friends. Courtney is one of the longer lasting and more memorable friends. In 1988, Skipper had a much-needed redesign. The 1984 "Hot Stuff" Skipper face mold was very scary and constantly making Skipper look like her hairline receded. The dolls bodies also changed, making Skipper an older teenager. She’s still quite a bit shorter than Barbie but she’s undoubtedly a teenager. In 1988, Skipper got a complete revamp with the new Teen Time and Teen Fun lines. She also got Courtney as her new best friend. The Pet Pals line featured Skipper, Courtney, and Kevin (Skipper’s boyfriend at the time) taking care of animals. Unlike Skipper and Kevin, Courtney comes with a cat. The others have dogs. For some weird reason, each of the dolls in this line come wearing animal themed jerseys. It reminds me too much of gym class ew. I’m not sure why they’re wearing these tacky things because it looks ridiculous and clashes with their outfits. Lucky for me, I got my doll secondhand without her outfit and wearing a Skipper Bridesmaid fashion pack that’s slightly less ugly. This doll has beautiful makeup and lovely crimped kanekalon hair which I appreciate. Sorry it’s hard to say much when I only have the base doll.
373: This is one of the many many slim boxed beach releases in the 90s. This line was glitter themed but also included colorful crystal necklaces on each doll. Barbie also came with a bottle of lotion that was advertised as being for the child and the doll. That lotion is long expired but even if it was in date I would not put it on my doll because that would make a mess. I think the bandanas/headbands each of the female dolls have are all really cute. Unfortunately my doll does not have hers or any piece of her bathing suit. The flower pattern is really darling and cute. I love the purples here that’s very slayful. Barbie’s makeup here is very Daniel-core with the near-garage doors of purple (for Jonah: garage doors is a drag term where you just use one solid eye shadow, as in your eyelid looks like a painted garage door). Barbie was still in her over-tanning era here and I worry about her health. I don’t really like Barbies with these kinds of arms because they just constantly look awkward. Like when are you going to stand like that? Never. This doll looks like she works in a diner and aspires to be a housewife (me too bestie).
383: This is yet another iconic 90s Barbie line. Interestingly, there was a deluxe Hollywood Hair doll released in a completely different outfit and dated 1993. I’m not sure which version I have because they are identical and I didn’t get any of her clothes, so I defaulted to the earlier one. These dolls are known for their really long hair. I’m lucky that my doll didn’t have a haircut. This was obviously a hairstyling doll, which I am not a big fan of because I am impatient and unskilled. Regardless of the version, this doll’s fit is so Saved by the Bell as in it was already out of date when it was released style-wise. It’s very tacky. However, I must say this doll has some of the most fabulous Barbie earrings that look amazing on her. Honestly I want a pair for myself. The best part of this doll by far is her makeup. Something about the way this screening is done completely transforms the Superstar face mold and it looks incredible.
423: The I Can Be line was so iconic to my childhood. I had no idea it existed all the way back in 2000. This release was also a Barbie and Kelly set. Barbie is Kelly’s pediatrician here. It also came with doctor playset pieces such as a weighing scale and various tools. Barbie being a doctor has been the norm for so long but I don’t know where this ranks among the various doctor Barbies. It took me a while to identify her because she was so glam that I assumed she was one of the slim boxed Teresas. I wasted a lot of time going through all the Teresas from this era, but identifying a doll is always worth it, no matter how long it takes. This doll has the Twist N Turn body which really stood out to me because her face looks like it belongs on the 1999 body. It’s weird because she’s so stiff and yet Kelly has additional articulation to accommodate the playset. This Barbie is so beautiful, especially in the dress I found her in. It took me a little longer to identify the dress because it came from a fashion pack, but it is 2000 Barbie Fashion Avenue Premiere in New York 25701. I decided to photograph her wearing it because it just looks so good on her and I don’t have her original outfit at this time.
491: This is another one of Gideon’s dolls that he kindly gave to me. Unfortunately, it took me especially long to identify her because she had some pink stains on her face that needed the acne cream treatment. This doll also has a slight haircut, but it’s hard to tell because she was originally styled with a ponytail. In this series, which features Kelly and her friends cosplaying as adults, Marisa decides to be a flight attendant. It reminds me a lot of Jan’s Night of a Thousand Michelle Visages runway on Season 12 of RuPaul’s Drag Race. It’s very cute. I like how her lipstick matches her stewardess uniform. Oh I forgot to mention, Marisa is dressed up as an airline stewardess. None of the other dolls in the line are dressed for air travel so this was a strange choice but I’m not offended or anything.
428: The I Can Be line was Barbie’s main career series throughout the early 2000s and 2010s. I thought it was only a late 2000s to early 2010 series but I was wrong. I can’t find exact dates though so I apologize for that. Barbie has also been a babysitter many many times, going all thte way back to the early 1960s. This release was a 2-pack with Kelly in one of her last appearances. I got this doll used so I’m missing Kelly and all the accessories. I’m not that bothered though because this set came with a bathroom gimmick as Barbie seems to be potty training her sister once again. Where are their parents? Unfortunately, the one thing I do have for this doll is her ugly dress. I have no idea what that print is supposed to be but I’m not a fan. Interestingly, this doll has kanekalon hair but the stock pictures appear to use saran. There’s often variation with Barbie so this isn’t a big deal but I thought it was cool. This Barbie’s face is fairly generic but it reminds me a lot of the dolls from my later childhood so I appreciate her a lot. Her hair also features an extreme side part which looks a little silly but I wasn’t paying much attention to hair styles in 2009 so I can’t really judge.
430: Before they were universally disliked, Barbie collaborated with SeaWorld multiple times. The 2011 release featured a branded playset with small plastic animals that could do tricks. I’m guessing it’s a forced perspective moment but it looks a little silly. I got this doll secondhand so I’m missing the tiny playset and animals as well as parts of Barbie’s outfit. I do have her wetsuit and whistle though so that’s something. This doll has the big scary flat feet but interestingly, it’s my only doll with big feet to have the hollow hard plastic legs rather than the bend n snap rubbery ones. Unfortunately, my doll is super wonky and her eyes look very silly from almost every angle. I can’t do anything about that because I’m terrible at painting. I doubt Jonah would be willing do try either. Sorry Barbie. Another big problem with this doll is that she has pretty bad glue seepage, but it’s treatable. It’s just going to take some time. I feel bad for this Barbie because she’s so unfortunate and forever tied to a super unethical corporation so I promised to take care of her and be a good father.
431: Starting in the early 2010s, Mattel would release super budget Barbies in super slim boxes with simple Barbie-printed dresses and minimal accessories. The boxes would just say "Barbie" so the name Budget Chic Pinktastic is a common fan term I found online. I find these dolls super fascinating because of their composition. They remind me a lot of the My First Barbies from the 1980s because of their limited articulation. This dolls arms can only turn up and down and her neck can only turn left and right. This is super interesting to me because I have a similar budget doll from the early 2000s who has similar arm articulation but a full range of motion on her neck. This doll also has the 2009 body and full hip movement which surprised me. I know the 1966 bodies were fully phased out at this point but I’m not sure why they didn’t opt for the 1999 body. Another interesting thing about this doll and a lot of similar dolls from this time period is that they have non-removable necklaces. This was very helpful with identification so I appreciate it as an adult but I’m sure kids would be disappointed. This doll’s necklace features the Barbie silhouette in solid black which always slays. Barbie’s makeup is pretty standard for the time period, but what’s unusual is her hair. This doll has a middle part which is almost unheard of for the early 2010s. I really love it as someone whose been parting his hair in the middle since 8th grade. Unfortunately I did not get this doll with her original outfit and at this time I have not identified the one she is currently wearing because I forgot to do it. This doll reminds me of my childhood a lot because I would see dolls like her at CVS or other stores that otherwise wouldn’t have dolls. I would never buy them but they always made me happy to see my favorite thing in the world where they otherwise wouldn’t be.
435: I’ve explained Barbie Fashionistas before, so see Fashionistas #160 for more information. This doll is obviously a Ken, but the box just says Barbie so I just wanted to clear up any confusion. This doll has vitiligo, which is shown through printing, but I believe a different method is used for the face and the body. For the face, the printing is pixelated just as many Mattel screenings in the late 2010s-early 2020s are, but on the body it seems to use a more traditional printing method. Unfortunately, the body printing looks the most fragile, despite the higher budget method. I got this doll as a gift from Gideon so I’ll let him give a more subjective description. This Ken’s job is get dressed in the dark. He calls himself a fashionista, however, his outfit is not very cute. Aside from the clothes though, fashionista Ken #192 is a cutie pie. I like his big strong arms and other muscles ;) . I would like if his hair was actually hair, but I guess it’s still ok. His shoes are really dumb and they don’t even fit him well. They should at least be dark green (the best colour). He is definitely the token bi and probably trans guy in a friend group of straight girls. He likes to date men who look exactly like him and he also has a puppy that is extremely well trained. I’d probably meet him for coffee 7/10.
437: Before I start this description I need to issue an apology for the Margot face mold because I said mean things about it previously but it looks absolutely stunning here. It also looks like Margot Robbie and I love it. This doll was part of Wave 2 of the Barbie movie dolls, and one of the few Barbies because apparently Ken is more important. I’m warning you now the remainder of this description contains spoilers for the Barbie movie but even Jonah’s seen it (only because I made him go with me) so I don’t think that’s a big deal. Anyway, this is Barbie’s outfit when the group start unbrainwashing the other Barbies. I wish they sold Allan in this outfit because that would be so slay. I guess a Michael Cera sculpt was not in the budget. This doll is a little simple but she’s so cute and beautiful. I was surprised she has a wedge boot (insert the Alyssa Edwards clip here) but I’m more surprised that I don’t hate it. The fabric on the jumpsuit surprised me with how nice it is. If I’m being honest, this was not my first choice of the Barbies but the rest of them are out of stock everywhere. I still really like this doll though and any Barbie movie doll is special to me because it reminds me of the special day I spent with my friends.
424: Before the flop era, Barbie’s budget/slim boxed dolls always slayed, sometimes more than the standard or deluxe dolls. This doll is a great example of that. Her dress is so 2001 and I love it. Usually, I deep clean all my boxed dolls just in case but with this one I didn’t want to fade the sparkle decals. I did wash her hair though because her hair elastic dry rotted unfortunately. The shoes are a very weird choice here, they’re the chunky short boots I always associate with 2009 I Can Be a Racecar Driver Barbie. I don’t know if that was en vouge in 2001 but it seems like a very strange choice and does not match the rest of the look. This doll’s face is so beautiful, it’s the type of screening I grew up with so it’s very nostalgic to me on top of being absolutely gorgina. I’m surprised that this doll has blue eyes because green eyes were very common with holiday themed Barbies at the time.
426: I’m going to start this by saying this doll was an adult collector release, themed around fancy elaborate chairs, which of course they came with. The line also included a white tiger and a leopard. This is such an interesting and bizarre release. The packaging choice decided to use a PIPE CLEANER to attach the doll to the couch. I’ve never seen that before but there’s a first time for everything I guess. At first I thought it was sewn into her bodysuit so I was worried that she’d have a massive red pipe cleaner coming out of her back in the picture. Lucky for you, dear reader (let’s be real the only person reading this is Jonah and that’s if I’m lucky) I managed to get it off. All the elastics dry rotted, and that has left a slight mark on her ankles I can’t do anything about at this time because I can’t wash her bodysuit (which is attached to the tights/boots) because the faux leather will definitely peel. Speaking of, I am afraid to breathe on this doll too much so her clothes don’t peel off. Despite how delicate it is, this outfit is fabulous, but also cursed because like I said, the shoes are attached to the entire bodysuit. It reminds me of those cursed Converse leggings from like 2010. The fluffy accents are very cute though, but I wish the tail was more obviously bendable. It took me a while to realize it had any flexibility which is no fun. Now that I’m done complaining about the outfit, I’m going to tell you how weird her hair is. Usually I wash out all the crusty hair gel because yuck. However, the cat ears are her hair but gelled and cut to look like the right shape. I’m not sure how the construction works because I’m too scared to investigate. Even without the weird "ears" (Jonah I forgot how to do quotes please help) her hair is weird because she has a pixie cut which is extremely rare for Barbie. I’m here for it though. Even though she’s really weird this doll slays. Also if you want to see the couch look it up yourself this is Daniel’s Dolls not Daniel’s Doll Furniture.
